metadata.case_name: Petition by Advocate enrolled in Madras High Court

facts.text: Petitioner enrolled in Madras High Court on November 15, 1955 under the Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926.
Petitioner admitted to the rolls of Supreme Court on October 29, 1960 under Order IV of the Supreme Court Rules as then stood.
Petitioner is an Advocate entitled to practise in Supreme Court under Advocates Act, 1961.
Petition filed challenging validity of Rule 16 of Order IV of Supreme Court Rules as amended in 1962.
Prayer for declaration that Rule 16 is ultra vires and petitioner entitled to practise as Advocate on Record without complying with Rule 16.

Rule 16: No Advocate qualified as Advocate on Record unless (1) undergone training for one year with approved Advocate on Record and passed tests notified in Gazette (Attorneys exempted); (2) has office in Delhi within 10 miles of Court House and undertaking to employ registered clerk within one month; (3) pays Rs. 25 fee.
Rule 17: Advocate on Record entitled to act as well as plead on filing memorandum of appearance with Vakalatnama. No other Advocate entitled to file appearance or act.
Every Advocate on common roll under s.20 Advocates Act entitled to plead, but only registered Advocates on Record entitled to act.

legal_issues.text: Proper construction of Art. 145(1)(a) of the Constitution in context of prayer for declaration that Rule 16 of Order IV of Supreme Court Rules is invalid.
Whether impugned Rules 16 and 17 are valid exercises of rule-making power under Art. 145(1)(a), or ultra vires in light of s.58(3) Advocates Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: As Advocate entitled to practise in Supreme Court under Advocates Act, 1961, entitled as of right not merely to plead but also to act; rules prescribing qualifications to act are invalid.
Right to practise includes right to plead and act; rules under Art.145 subject to parliamentary law like s.58(3), which grants absolute right not controlled by rules.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.145(1)(a) Constitution; Aswini Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose (1953 SCR 1)

petitioner_arguments.text: Art.145(1)(a) 'rules as to the persons practising before the Court' narrower than 'persons entitled to practise' (Entry 77 List I); cannot prescribe qualifications or entitlement, only regulate conduct of those already entitled by Parliament.

respondent_arguments.text: Words 'persons practising before the Court' in Art.145(1)(a) not narrower than 'persons entitled to practise'; comprehensive to include prescribing qualifications for entitlement.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.145(1)(a); s.214(1) Govt of India Act 1935

respondent_arguments.text: Rules justified under inherent powers of Court.

court_reasoning.text: s.58(3) Advocates Act entitles petitioner to practise as of right subject to rules made by Supreme Court; right to practise includes plead and act if no rules, but subject to rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.58(3) expressly subjects right to rules made by Supreme Court.

court_reasoning.text: s.52 Advocates Act saves Supreme Court's rule-making power under Art.145, including determining persons entitled to act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No conflict with parliamentary law due to savings in s.52.

court_reasoning.text: Art.145(1)(a) 'rules as to the persons practising before the Court' is independent head of power, not limited to regulating conduct of those already entitled; includes prescribing qualifications for entitlement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'including' and subject matter stamp it as independent; drawn from s.214(1) Govt of India Act 1935, under which Federal Court prescribed qualifications.

court_reasoning.text: No anomaly in Court prescribing qualifications subject to override by parliamentary law per opening words of Art.145.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules operate subject to laws made by Parliament.

court_reasoning.text: Aswini Kumar Ghosh distinguished as based on implied repeal by specific enactment overriding High Court rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Does not carry matter far here.

holdings.text: Impugned Rules 16 and 17 valid and within rule-making power under express terms of Art.145(1)(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Aswini Kumar Ghosh and Anr. v. Arabinda Bose and Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: Explained 'right to practise' includes plead and act; held 1951 Act prevailed over High Court rules, but distinguished as implied repeal not applicable here.
Inherent powers of Supreme Court referred to, but not relied upon as decision rests on Art.145(1)(a).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers Supreme Court to make rules as to persons practising before the Court, held sufficient for Rules 16 and 17.

statutes_cited.name: Advocates Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: s.58(3) grants right to practise subject to SC rules; s.52 saves Art.145 powers including determining persons entitled to act.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Bar Councils Act, 1926
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitioner enrolled thereunder; referenced in s.58(3).

statutes_cited.name: Supreme Court Advocates (Practice in High Courts) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Cited in Aswini Kumar for 'right to practise' meaning plead and act.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Precursor to Art.145(1)(a); Federal Court used similar words to prescribe qualifications for Advocates.

outcome.summary: Petition challenging validity of Rule 16 Order IV Supreme Court Rules dismissed; rules held valid under Art.145(1)(a).

key_quotes.text: 'right to practise would in its normal connotation take in, not merely right to plead but the right to act as well'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms petitioner's view on scope of right, but holds subject to rules.

key_quotes.text: We are inclined to read item (a) as an independent head of rule making power and not as merely a part of a power to make rules for regulating the practice and procedure of the Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on construction of Art.145(1)(a).

key_quotes.text: the words persons practising before the Court were then used in a comprehensive sense so as to include a rule not merely as to the manner of practice but also of the right to practise
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets scope based on historical usage.
